creatures.name: Centaur
creatures.description: A centaur is a creature with the upper body of a human and the lower body of a horse.
creatures.funfact: The centaur was a popular subject in Greek art

creatures.name: Unicorn
creatures.description: A unicorn is a mythical creature that has been described since antiquity as a beast with a single large, pointed, spiraling horn projecting from its forehead.
creatures.funfact: Unicorns were said to contain healing properties. For example, if you drank from a cup made out of a unicorn horn, you would be protected from poisons.

creatures.name: Dragon
creatures.habitat: dank caves, deep pools, wild mountain reaches, sea bottoms, haunted forests
creatures.description: Dragons are giant serpent-like, winged monsters that have been featured in myths from all around the world.
creatures.funfact: Dragons vary in apperance from culture to culture, but they are often depicted as having a long body, four legs, and a pair of wings.

creatures.name: Cyclopes
creatures.description: A one-eyed giant
creatures.funfact: the cyclopes lived in isolation and tended sheep or goats without any government, society, or community. While scorned for their lawlessness, it was the cyclopes who created Zeus’ thunderbolts, Hades helmet which made the wearer invisible, Poseidon’s trident, and Artemis’ silver bow.

creatures.name: Ogre
creatures.description: They are inhumanly large, tall, and having a disproportionately large head, abundant hair, unusually colored skin, a voracious appetite, and a strong body. Ogres are closely linked with giants and with human cannibals in mythology.
creatures.funfact: The word ogre is of French origin, originally derived from the Etruscan god Orcus, who fed on human flesh.

creatures.name: Leprechaun
creatures.description: Usually depicted as little bearded men, wearing a coat and hat, who partake in mischief.
creatures.funfact: Humans are said to capture the Leprechaun, refusing to release him until the Leprechaun gives his captor supernatural wealth

creatures.name: Golem
creatures.description: Created from inanimate matter (usually clay or mud)
creatures.funfact: In some stories, a golem is created to defend against antisemitic attacks. According to legend, golems are uniquely obedient and will follow exact and literal orders, so their creators definitely had to be careful with what they asked them to do.

creatures.name: Oni
creatures.description: Giant, scary monsters with red or blue skin, horns, and tusks
creatures.funfact: Oni are people who were so truly wicked in their lives that they transformed into demons in hell. Some were even bad enough to be transformed while still alive! They enact violent punishment on evil-doers and will eat just about anything, including humans.

creatures.name: Gnome
creatures.description: creatures resembling little old men, often with hunched over backs
creatures.funfact: They guarded underground treasures.

creatures.name: Fairy
creatures.description: Fairies are generally described as human in appearance and having magical powers. Diminutive fairies of various kinds have been reported through centuries, ranging from quite tiny to the size of a human.
creatures.funfact: In the folklore fairies flew by means of magic, sometimes perched on ragwort stems or the backs of birds.

creatures.name: Mermaid
creatures.description: An aquatic creature with the head and upper body of a female human and the tail of a fish.
creatures.funfact: Mermaids are sometimes associated with perilous events such as floods, storms, shipwrecks, and drownings. In other folk traditions (or sometimes within the same traditions), they can be benevolent or beneficent, bestowing boons or falling in love with humans.

creatures.name: Akrabuamelu
creatures.habitat: Guards outside the gate of the sun.
creatures.description: Head, torso, and arms of a man and the body of a scorpion.
creatures.funfact: While they are terrifying in appearance and were created to wage war against gods, they also stand as guardians and often warn travelers who might be in danger.

creatures.name: Minotaur
creatures.description: Head and tail of a bull and the body of a man.
creatures.funfact: From classical antiquity through the Renaissance, the Minotaur appears at the center of many depictions of the Labyrinth.[

creatures.name: Faun
creatures.description: legs and tail of a goat and the upper body of a man
creatures.funfact: Originally fauns of Roman mythology were spirits (genii) of rustic places, lesser versions of their chief, the god Faunus. Before their conflation with Greek satyrs, they and Faunus were represented as nude men (e.g. the Barberini Faun). Later fauns, became copies of the satyrs of Greek mythology, who themselves were originally shown as part-horse rather than part-goat.

creatures.name: Werewolf
creatures.description: A human who can transform or shapeshift into a wolf.
creatures.funfact: Not in every folklore the werewolf transformed by the fullmoon.

creatures.name: Griffin
creatures.description: A hybrid of a lion and an eagle.
creatures.funfact: Because the lion was traditionally considered the king of the beasts, and the eagle the king of the birds, by the Middle Ages, the griffin was thought to be an especially powerful and majestic creature. Since classical antiquity, griffins were known for guarding treasures and priceless possessions.

creatures.name: Phoenix
creatures.description: A bird-creature with colorful feathers.
creatures.funfact: The phoenix is an immortal bird that cyclically regenerates or is otherwise born again. Associated with the sun, a phoenix obtains new life by rising from the ashes of its predecessor. Some legends say it dies in a show of flames and combustion, others that it simply dies and decomposes before being born again.

creatures.name: Basilisk
creatures.description: A snake.
creatures.funfact: legendary reptile reputed to be a serpent king, who causes death to those who look into its eyes. According to the Naturalis Historia of Pliny the Elder, the basilisk of Cyrene is a small snake, "being not more than twelve inches in length", that is so venomous, it leaves a wide trail of deadly venom in its wake, and its gaze is likewise lethal.

creatures.name: Chimera
creatures.description: a lion merged with a goat and a snake, which was related to monsters such as Cerberus.
creatures.funfact: The term "chimera" has come to describe any mythical or fictional creature with parts taken from various animals, to describe anything composed of disparate parts or perceived as wildly imaginative, implausible, or dazzling.

creatures.name: Hydra
creatures.habitat: he lake of Lerna in the Argolid
creatures.description: A serpentine with many heads.
creatures.funfact: It had poisonous breath and blood so virulent that even its scent was deadly. Later versions of the Hydra story add a regeneration feature to the monster: for every head chopped off, the Hydra would regrow two heads.

creatures.name: Banshee
creatures.description: Sometimes she has long streaming hair and wears a grey cloak over a green dress, and her eyes are red from continual weeping.
creatures.funfact: The banshee also is a predictor of death. If someone is about to enter a situation where it is unlikely they will come out alive she will warn people by screaming or wailing, giving rise to a banshee also being known as a wailing woman.

creatures.name: Dybbuk
creatures.description: A malicious possessing spirit believed to be the dislocated soul of a dead person.
creatures.funfact: It supposedly leaves the host body once it has accomplished its goal, sometimes after being exorcised.

creatures.name: Vampire
creatures.description: The most predominant feature of vampires (or vampyres) is the consumption of a person’s vital essence, most often in the form of blood.
creatures.funfact: It’s interesting to note that the pale and sophisticated vampire which has become commonplace in the media did not exist before the 19th century.

creatures.name: Baku
creatures.description: According to legend, they were created by the spare pieces that were left over when the gods finished creating all other animals.
creatures.funfact: They are said to devour our nightmares. In the 1910s, it was common for Japanese children to keep a baku talisman at their bedside.

creatures.name: Futakuchi onna
creatures.description: They are characterized by their two mouths – a normal one located on her face and a second one on the back of the head beneath the hair. There, the woman's skull splits apart, forming lips, teeth and a tongue, creating an entirely functional second mouth.
creatures.funfact: The origin of a futakuchi-onna's second mouth is often linked to how little a woman eats.[1] In many stories, the soon-to-be futakuchi-onna is a wife of a miser and rarely eats. To counteract this, a second mouth mysteriously appears on the back of the woman's head. The second mouth often mumbles spiteful and threatening things to the woman and demands food. If it is not fed, it can screech obscenely and cause the woman tremendous pain. Eventually, the woman's hair begins to move like a pair of serpents, allowing the mouth to help itself to the woman's meals. While no food passes through her normal lips, the mouth in the back of her head consumes twice than the other one would

creatures.name: Tenko or Sky fox
creatures.description: After reaching 1,000 years of age and gaining its ninth tail, a fox spirit turns a golden color, becoming a sky fox, the most powerful form of the fox spirit, and then ascends to the heavens.
creatures.funfact: "Every 100 years, a catastrophe occurs. It was believed that if a fox could go through it smoothly, it will grow a new tail. The number of nine-tailed foxes is small because many foxes unfortunately interrupted their practice of self-cultivation or died during the 3~5 tail period. When the fox reaches 1,000 years of age, it will become the Thousand-Year Heavenly Fox, formally gaining the Heavenly Court's canonization and obtaining the Immortal Rank"

creatures.name: Kappa
creatures.description: They are typically depicted as green, human-like beings with webbed hands and feet and a turtle-like carapace on their back.
creatures.funfact: Their actions range from comparatively minor misdemeanors, such as looking up women's kimono if they venture too near to water, to outright malevolence, such as drowning people and animals, kidnapping children, raping women and at times eating human flesh.

creatures.name: Ōmukade
creatures.description: A giant man-eating centipede.
creatures.funfact: It eats humans, but has a weakness to human saliva. It also preys on great serpents and dragons.

creatures.name: Troll
creatures.habitat: Mountains, under bridges, and at the bottom of lakes
creatures.description: A big monster with many heads.
creatures.funfact: Trolls are described in many ways in Scandinavian folk literature, but they are often portrayed as stupid, and slow to act. In fairy tales and legends about trolls, the plot is often that a human with courage and presence of mind can outwit a troll.

creatures.name: Elves
creatures.description: Female, otherwordly beautiful with magic abilities.
creatures.funfact: ometimes they are described as small fairies, sometimes as full-sized women and sometimes as half transparent spirits, or a mix thereof. They are closely linked to the mist and it is often said in Sweden that, "the Elves are dancing in the mist".

creatures.name: Hulder
creatures.description: Though described as beautiful, the huldra is noted for having a distinctive inhuman feature—an animal's tail (usually a cow's or a fox's) and/or a back resembling a hollowed-out tree.
creatures.funfact: The hulder is one of several rå (keeper, warden), including the aquatic sjörå or havsfru, later identified with a mermaid, and the bergsrå in caves and mines who made life tough for the poor miners.

creatures.name: Näcken
creatures.description: A shapeshifting water spirits
creatures.funfact: Excists in various types in the different folklores; in Swedish folklore he was male, played violin and lured people into the water

creatures.name: Nisse or Gårdstomte
creatures.description: A small, elderly man; short, have a long white beard, and wear a conical or knit cap in gray, red or some other bright colour.
creatures.funfact: Takes care of the house and barn when the farmer is asleep, but only if the farmer reciprocates by setting out food for the nisse and he himself also takes care of his family, farm and animals. If the nisse is ignored or maltreated or the farm is not cared for, he is likely to sabotage the work instead to teach the farmer a lesson.
